TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in PERSON .
CARDINAL . The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

CARDINAL . The applicant worked as a carpet maker for ORG , a company registered in PERSON ( “ the employer ” ) . On DATE she was declared to be a person with second degree disabilities by a specialised medical commission , which recommended that the applicant should stop working as a carpet maker as her working conditions were damaging her health .

CARDINAL . Having submitted the relevant certificate to her employer , on DATE the applicant was dismissed from her job on the grounds that she was no longer able to work as a result of her invalidity . She disagreed with the reason for her dismissal , claiming that this was not a valid legal reason . She asked her employer to issue her with a record of employment ( carnet de muncă ) giving a different reason for her dismissal , a document which she would have to produce if she applied for another job . On DATE the employer issued her with a record of employment , which she claims was in the old format , contrary to the law .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant initiated court proceedings against the employer , asking for a modification of the reason for her dismissal , the issuing of a new record of employment and the payment of her salary and compensation for the entire period during which she had not been issued with a new record of employment .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG left her action without examination . On DATE the ORG quashed that decision and ordered the examination of her action .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG found against the applicant . On DATE the ORG quashed that judgment and adopted a new one , partly admitting the applicant 's claims and awarding her compensation . On DATE ORG quashed the judgments of the lower courts and ordered a full re - trial of the case .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG found for the applicant and awarded her compensation . On DATE ORG partly quashed that judgment and adopted a new one , ordering the employer to issue the applicant with a new record of employment , and in addition to pay her compensation in the amount of CARDINAL NORP lei ( MDL ) ( QUANTITY ( ORG ) at the time ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE the employer lodged an appeal in cassation , asking the court to reject the applicant 's claims . It also requested the court to accept its right to lodge the appeal despite having missed the CARDINAL-day time - limit established by law , because it had not participated at the court hearing of CARDINAL DATE and had only been informed of the judgment by mail on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG accepted the employer 's appeal and quashed the lower courts ' judgments , rejecting all of the applicant 's claims . The court found that there was clear evidence of the applicant 's refusal to take her record of employment on DATE of her dismissal ( DATE ) , as well as of the fact that on DATE she had taken her record of employment . CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of the new Code of Civil Procedure read :

( CARDINAL ) ORG actions shall be examined by the first - instance court within a reasonable time . The criteria for determining the reasonable length of the proceedings include : the complexity of the case , the conduct of the parties to the proceedings and the conduct of the court . ( CARDINAL ) ORG actions regarding ... work related claims ... shall be examined urgently and on a priority basis . ”
